content.body: just noticed a fascinating thing about https://tc39.es/ecma262/#sec-math.log10e

the spec notes that
> The value of Math.LOG10E is approximately the reciprocal of the value of Math.LN10.
but

the spec notes that

The value of Math.LOG10E is approximately the reciprocal of the value of Math.LN10.
but

content.body: whereas `1/Math.log(2) === Math.log2(Math.E)` and therefore `Math.LOG2E` can be defined either way,
content.formatted_body: whereas 1/Math.log(2) === Math.log2(Math.E) and therefore Math.LOG2E can be defined either way,

content.body: `1/Math.log(10) !== Math.log10(Math.E)` and therefore `Math.LOG10E` needs to be defined as the latter
content.formatted_body: 1/Math.log(10) !== Math.log10(Math.E) and therefore Math.LOG10E needs to be defined as the latter

content.body:
i.e.
```
λ eshost -se "[Math.LOG10E, Math.log10(Math.E), 1/Math.log(10)]"
#### engine262, JavaScriptCore, SpiderMonkey, V8
0.4342944819032518,0.4342944819032518,0.43429448190325176
```
content.formatted_body:
i.e.

λ eshost -se "[Math.LOG10E, Math.log10(Math.E), 1/Math.log(10)]"
#### engine262, JavaScriptCore, SpiderMonkey, V8
0.4342944819032518,0.4342944819032518,0.43429448190325176

content.body: I guess this might not be that interesting from V8's perspective, where `log2(kE)` `log10(kE)` are being used, but
content.formatted_body: I guess this might not be that interesting from V8's perspective, where log2(kE) log10(kE) are being used, but

content.body: for 15 years, JSC has had these defined as `1.0 / Math::log(2.0)` and `0.4342944819032518`, and I was like, huh that's weird
